query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 «Pape Satàn, pape Satàn aleppe!», 2 cominciò Pluto con la voce chioccia; 3 e quel savio gentil, che tutto seppe,
4 disse per confortarmi: «Non ti noccia 5 la tua paura; ché, poder ch’elli abbia, 6 non ci torrà lo scender questa roccia».
query.result:
**English:**
1 "Pape Satan, pape Satan aleppe!", 2 began Pluto with his hoarse voice; 3 and that wise and gentle sage, who knew all things,
4 said to comfort me: "Let not your fear harm you; 5 for, whatever power he may have, 6 he cannot prevent us from descending this rock."
**Old English:**
1 "Papa Sātan, papa Sātan aleppe!", 2 ongann Plūtō mid pāre hēsan stefne; 3 and ðā gesæliga and snotera guma, sē ðe eall wiste,
4 cwæð mē tō frōfre: "Nē ðē forhted þīn ege; 5 forðæm, swā hwæt swā hē mæge, 6 nē mæg hē ūs bewerian ðisne stān ofer tō stigenne."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Poi si rivolse a quella ’nfiata labbia, 8 e disse: «Taci, maladetto lupo! 9 consuma dentro te con la tua rabbia.
query.result:
**English:**
7 Then he turned to that swollen muzzle, 8 and said: "Be silent, cursed wolf! 9 Consume yourself with your own rage.
**Old English:**
7 Þa he gewende him to ðære swiðran sidan, 8 and cwæð: "Swiga, ðu awyrgda wulf! 9 Fornim ðe selfne mid ðinum graman."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Non è sanza cagion l’andare al cupo: 11 vuolsi ne l’alto, là dove Michele 12 fé la vendetta del superbo strupo».
query.result:
**English:**
10 It is not without reason that one goes to the deep: 11 one must go up high, there where Michael 12 took vengeance for the proud theft.
**Old English:**
10 Nis hit ðurh ðone unsped ðæt mon sceal to ðam deopan gangan: 11 mon sceal on ðæt heage stigan, ðær ðær Michael 12 ðæs ofermodes wracu gefremede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Quali dal vento le gonfiate vele 14 caggiono avvolte, poi che l’alber fiacca, 15 tal cadde a terra la fiera crudele.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Like sails filled with wind 14 that fall collapsed when the mast breaks, 15 so the fierce beast fell to the ground.
**Old English:**
13 Swa ða segl ða wind gebliss ða 14 fealleð niðer, ðonne ðæt scip breceð, 15 swa ða ðeor ðær to eorðan feoll.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Così scendemmo ne la quarta lacca, 17 pigliando più de la dolente ripa 18 che ’l mal de l’universo tutto insacca.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Thus we descended into the fourth chasm, 17 taking more of the sorrowful bank 18 that ensnares the evil of the entire universe.
**Old English:**
16 Þus we stigon niðer on ða feorðan lace, 17 nimendum mare ðære sarigean ripe 18 ðe ðæs yfles ealles onwrið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Ahi giustizia di Dio! tante chi stipa 20 nove travaglie e pene quant’ io viddi? 21 e perché nostra colpa sì ne scipa?
22 Come fa l’onda là sovra Cariddi, 23 che si frange con quella in cui s’intoppa, 24 così convien che qui la gente riddi.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Ah, justice of God! How many souls are crowded 20 into new travails and punishments, as I saw? 21 And why does our fault so strip us?
22 As the wave does there above Charybdis, 23 that breaks against the one it meets, 24 so here the people must dance.
**Old English:**
19 Eala, Godes rihtwisnes! Hu fela ðara 20 niwra geswinca and ðreora ðe ic ðær geseah? 21 And for hwi ðolige we ðæt ure gyltas swa us bismrið?
22 Swa ðæt wæg gelið ðær ofer Cariddi, 23 ðe ðær tosliteð wið ða ðe him toweard bið, 24 swa ðearf her monna gehwylc ymb cyrran.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Qui vid’ i’ gente più ch’altrove troppa, 26 e d’una parte e d’altra, con grand’ urli, 27 voltando pesi per forza di poppa.
query.result:
**English:**
25 There I saw more people than elsewhere, 26 and on one side and the other, with great shouts, 27 they were pushing weights by force of chest.
**Old English:**
25 Þær ic geseah ða leode ma þonne elles hwar, 26 and on ægðre healfe, mid miclum hreame, 27 wrixlendne byrðene for breostgewrixle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Percotëansi ’ncontro; e poscia pur lì 29 si rivolgea ciascun, voltando a retro, 30 gridando: «Perché tieni?» e «Perché burli?».
query.result:
**English:**
28 They struck each other; and then, right there, 29 each turned around, turning back, 30 shouting: “Why are you holding on?” and “Why are you pushing?”
**Old English:**
28 Hi tosomne slogon; and ða sona eft 29 hi gewendon him bæc, hweorfende, 30 cleopiende: “Hwæt lætst ðu?” and “Hwæt lyhst ðu?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
36 E io, ch’avea lo cor quasi compunto,
37 dissi: «Maestro mio, or mi dimostra 38 che gente è questa, e se tutti fuor cherci 39 questi chercuti a la sinistra nostra».
query.result:
**English:**
36 And I, whose heart was almost pricked,
37 said: "My Master, now show me 38 what people these are, and if all those tonsured 39 on our left were clerics."
**Old English:**
36 And ic, ðe hæfde ðone heortan nean gebrocen,
37 cwæð: "La, min lareow, nu ðu me asecge 38 hwæt ðis folc sy, and gif ða ealle wæron clercas 39 ða gesorene on ðære wynstran healfe."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Ed elli a me: «Tutti quanti fuor guerci 41 sì de la mente in la vita primaia, 42 che con misura nullo spendio ferci.
query.result:
**English:**
40 And he to me: "All of them were squint-eyed 41 in their minds in the first life, 42 so that they made no expenditure with measure.
**Old English:**
40 And he to me: "Ealle ða wæron gesihðe bedælede 41 on ðam mode on ðam forman life, 42 ðæt hi mid gemete nænne gylp ne dydon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Assai la voce lor chiaro l’abbaia, 44 quando vegnono a’ due punti del cerchio 45 dove colpa contraria li dispaia.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Their barking is very clear to him, 44 when they come to the two points of the circle 45 where opposite faults separate them.
**Old English:**
43 Swiðe ðeorcende wæs heora hundes stemne, 44 ða ða hi comon to ðam twam endebyrdnessum ðæs hweorfes, 45 ðær ða widerwearðan gyltas hi tosliton.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Questi fuor cherci, che non han coperchio 47 piloso al capo, e papi e cardinali, 48 in cui usa avarizia il suo soperchio».
query.result:
**English:**
46 These were clerics who have no covering 47 of hair on their heads, and popes and cardinals, 48 in whom avarice practices its excess.
**Old English:**
46 Þas wæron clericas ðe næfdon nænne hrof 47 hærgimm on heafde, and papan and cardinales, 48 on ðam awyrgð hire oferflowað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 E io: «Maestro, tra questi cotali 50 dovre’ io ben riconoscere alcuni 51 che furo immondi di cotesti mali».
query.result:
**English:**
49 And I: "Master, among these such 50 I should indeed recognize some 51 who were defiled with these evils."
**Old English:**
49 And ic: "Lareow, betwux ðissum folce 50 sceal ic ful georne sume ongitan 51 ðe ðurh ðas leahtras wæron besmitene."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Ed elli a me: «Vano pensiero aduni: 53 la sconoscente vita che i fé sozzi, 54 ad ogne conoscenza or li fa bruni.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And he to me: "You gather vain thoughts: 53 the unknown life which made them vile, 54 now makes them dark to every understanding.
**Old English:**
52 And he to me: "Þu ydele ðohtas gaderast: 53 ðæt uncuðe lif ðe hi afylde, 54 ðæt hi ða sindon to ælcon andgite ðystro."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 In etterno verranno a li due cozzi: 56 questi resurgeranno del sepulcro 57 col pugno chiuso, e questi coi crin mozzi.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Eternally will they come to the two buttings: 56 these will rise again from the sepulcher 57 with clenched fist, and these with hair cropped.
**Old English:**
55 On ecnesse cumao to ðam twam cohhum: 56 ðas ða of ðam byrgene bregaoð 57 mid locenum gefean, ðas mid locenum hearme.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Mal dare e mal tener lo mondo pulcro 59 ha tolto loro, e posti a questa zuffa: 60 qual ella sia, parole non ci appulcro.
query.result:
**English:**
58 To give badly and to hold badly the beautiful world 59 has taken them away from them, and placed them in this fight: 60 whatever it is, words do not beautify it for us.
**Old English:**
58 Yfele to gyfanne and yfele to healdenne ðone fægeran middangeard 59 hæfð hi ofnumen, and on ðas wrohte gesett: 60 hwilc heo sy, ðæt ne mæg nænig word awritan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 «Maestro mio», diss’ io, «or mi dì anche: 68 questa fortuna di che tu mi tocche, 69 che è, che i ben del mondo ha sì tra branche?».
query.result:
**English:**
67 "My master," I said, "now tell me also: 68 this fortune that you mention to me, 69 what is it, that it holds the goods of the world in its clutches?"
**Old English:**
67 "Lareow min," cwæð ic, "nu ðu me sæge: 68 ðeos wyrd ðe ðu me on wrigen hæfst, 69 hwæt heo is, ðe ðæs weoroldwelan on geweald hafað?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E quelli a me: «Oh creature sciocche, 71 quanta ignoranza è quella che v’offende! 72 Or vo’ che tu mia sentenza ne ’mbocche.
query.result:
**English:**
70 And those to me: "Oh foolish creatures, 71 how much ignorance is that which offends you! 72 Now I want you to take my judgment into your mouth.
**Old English:**
70 And ða ða to me: "Eala ðu sceocca wiht, 71 hu micel is ðin unwisdom ðe ðe awergeð! 72 Nu ic wille ðæt ðu minne dôm on ðinum muðe bere.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Colui lo cui saver tutto trascende, 74 fece li cieli e diè lor chi conduce 75 sì, ch’ogne parte ad ogne parte splende,
76 distribuendo igualmente la luce.
query.result:
**English:**
73 He whose knowledge transcends all things, 74 made the heavens and gave them their guides, 75 so that every part shines upon every other part,
76 distributing the light equally.
**Old English:**
73 Se ðe ðæs wisdom eall ðurhsihoð, 74 geworhte heofon and him gesceafte sette, 75 ðæt æghwylc oðrum onliht,
76 and ða beorhtan gesceaft gelice dælde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
77 Similemente a li splendor mondani 78 ordinò general ministra e duce
79 che permutasse a tempo li ben vani 80 di gente in gente e d’uno in altro sangue, 81 oltre la difension d’i senni umani;
82 per ch’una gente impera e l’altra langue, 83 seguendo lo giudicio di costei, 84 che è occulto come in erba l’angue.
query.result:
**English:**
77 Similarly, to worldly splendors 78 she ordained a general minister and guide,
79 who would redistribute in time the vain goods 80 from people to people and from one bloodline to another, 81 beyond the defense of human reason;
82 so that one people rules and another languishes, 83 following the judgment of this one, 84 which is hidden like a snake in the grass.
**Old English:**
77 Swilce eac ða worldlican wuldor 78 heo gesette ðæm anweald and ðone heretogan,
79 ðæt he ða yðlan god bebyrigde 80 fram folce to folce and fram gebyrdum to gebyrdum, 81 ofer ðæs mannes geðohtes mæðe;
82 ðurh ðæt an folc rixað and oðer ðolað, 83 æfter ðæs anwealdes dome, 84 ðe is digle swilce næddre on gærs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Vostro saver non ha contasto a lei: 86 questa provede, giudica, e persegue 87 suo regno come il loro li altri dèi.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Your knowledge has no power against her: 86 she provides, judges, and rules 87 her kingdom just as the other gods do theirs.
**Old English:**
85 Eower witen ne mæg wið ða wendan: 86 heo ðæt ræt, and ðæt gerihð, and ðone ræd 87 hyre rīces wealdeð swa ða oðre godas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Le sue permutazion non hanno triegue: 89 necessità la fa esser veloce; 90 sì spesso vien chi vicenda consegue.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Its permutations have no truce: 89 necessity makes it swift; 90 so often does he come who achieves change.
**Old English:**
88 Hire ymbhwyrft næfre ne geswicað: 89 neod hire wyrðeð ðæt heo wæs hraðe; 90 swiðe oft cymeð se ðe wrixl getihð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Or discendiamo omai a maggior pieta; 98 già ogne stella cade che saliva 99 quand’ io mi mossi, e ’l troppo star si vieta».
query.result:
**English:**
97 Now let us descend to greater pity; 98 already every star is falling that was rising 99 when I set out, and to linger too long is forbidden.
**Old English:**
97 Nu wuton we nu nyðer stigan to maran miltsunge; 98 nu ælc steorra fealleð þe ær up astah 99 ða ic me on weg awende, and to lange standan is forboden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Noi ricidemmo il cerchio a l’altra riva 101 sovr’ una fonte che bolle e riversa 102 per un fossato che da lei deriva.
query.result:
**English:**
100 We cut across to the other bank 101 over a spring that bubbles and pours 102 through a ditch that flows from it.
**Old English:**
100 We ða ofer ðone weall stigon 101 ofer ðone burn ðe of ðære wylle com, 102 ðe ðurh ðone wudu wæs wylmestreame.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 L’acqua era buia assai più che persa; 104 e noi, in compagnia de l’onde bige, 105 intrammo giù per una via diversa.
query.result:
**English:**
103 The water was dark, much darker than purple; 104 and we, in the company of the murky waves, 105 entered down through a different path.
**Old English:**
103 Wæs ðæt wæter swiðe ðiostor ðonne purpur; 104 and we on ðære blæcan brime, 105 on ðam mistceoledan mere, 106 ferdon forð on ðam fealwan flode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 In la palude va c’ha nome Stige 107 questo tristo ruscel, quand’ è disceso 108 al piè de le maligne piagge grige.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Into the marsh called Styx 107 this dismal stream, when it has descended 108 to the foot of the malignant gray slopes.
**Old English:**
106 On ðone mere ðe hatte Styx 107 ðeos dreorigh stream, ðonne he nyðer sígð 108 to ðæra yfla græga fotum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 E io, che di mirare stava inteso, 110 vidi genti fangose in quel pantano, 111 ignude tutte, con sembiante offeso.
query.result:
**English:**
109 And I, who was intent on watching, 110 saw muddy people in that swamp, 111 all naked, with offended countenances.
**Old English:**
109 And ic ðe ðær on starade ðe ða wundrode, 110 ic ðær geseah ða modgan folc on ðam wæte, 111 nacode ealle and mid gedrefedum andwlitum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Queste si percotean non pur con mano, 113 ma con la testa e col petto e coi piedi, 114 troncandosi co’ denti a brano a brano.
query.result:
**English:**
112 These beat each other not only with their hands, 113 but with their heads and chests and feet, 114 tearing themselves to pieces with their teeth.
**Old English:**
112 Þas beotað himsylfe na mid handa ana, 113 ac mid heafde and mid breoste and mid fotum, 114 slitende himsylfe mid teðum on styccum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Lo buon maestro disse: «Figlio, or vedi 116 l’anime di color cui vinse l’ira; 117 e anche vo’ che tu per certo credi
118 che sotto l’acqua è gente che sospira, 119 e fanno pullular quest’ acqua al summo, 120 come l’occhio ti dice, u’ che s’aggira.
query.result:
**English:**
115 The good master said: "Son, now you see 116 the souls of those whom anger overcame; 117 and I also want you to believe for certain
118 that under the water are people who sigh, 119 and they make this water bubble up to the surface, 120 as your eyes tell you, wherever you look.
**Old English:**
115 Se goda lareow cwæð: "Sunu, ðu nu gesihst 116 ðara sawla ðe ðam yrre ofercom; 117 and eac ic wille ðæt ðu to soðe gelyfe
118 ðæt under ðam wætere is folc ðe wepeð, 119 and ðone wæter ðurh ða wop up ahebbað, 120 swa ðin eage ðe sægð, ðær ðu hit ofersihst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Fitti nel limo dicon: “Tristi fummo 122 ne l’aere dolce che dal sol s’allegra, 123 portando dentro accidïoso fummo:
124 or ci attristiam ne la belletta negra”.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Stuck in the slime, they say: "We were sad 122 in the sweet air that is gladdened by the sun, 123 bearing sullen smoke within us:
124 now we are saddened in the black pitch".
**Old English:**
121 Fæste on ðam lime cwæðað: “We wæron sarige 122 on ðam swetan lyfte ðe of ðære sunnan bið blide, 123 berende innan us surhcearigne sméoc:
124 nu we us sarigeð on ðære sweartan picce”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
125 Quest’ inno si gorgoglian ne la strozza, 126 ché dir nol posson con parola integra».
127 Così girammo de la lorda pozza 128 grand’ arco tra la ripa secca e ’l mézzo, 129 con li occhi vòlti a chi del fango ingozza.
query.result:
**English:**
125 This hymn gurgles in their throats, 126 so that they cannot speak it with whole words.
127 Thus we went around the filthy pool 128 in a wide arc between the dry bank and the middle, 129 with our eyes turned to those who gorge themselves on the mud.
**Old English:**
125 Þeos lofsang gárgað on heora swelgan, 126 ðæt hý hit ne magon sprecan mid hálan worde.
127 Þus wé gewendon of ðære láðan pytte 128 micelne bogan betwux ðære drýgan ripe and ðæm midle, 129 mid úrum eagum bewende to ðæm ðe ðone fenn slepon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Venimmo al piè d’una torre al da sezzo.
query.result:
**English:**
130 We came to the foot of a tower at last.
**Old English:**
130 We comon ða to ðæs torres fot æt nextan.
